subject: probability
title: Stationary Distributions
contentHtml: A stochastic process has a stationary distribution if its probability distribution remains unchanged over time.

theorem.statement: \[\text{Let } X_t \text{ be a Markov chain. Then, } P(X_0 = x) = P(X_t = x) \text{ for all } t > 0.\]
theorem.proofSketch: The proof involves showing that the probability distribution of the process converges to a limiting distribution as time increases.

intuition: A stationary distribution represents the long-term behavior of a stochastic process, where the probability of being in each state remains constant over time.
realWorldApplications: PageRank algorithm in Google's search engine

subject: probability
title: Stationary Distributions Theorem
contentHtml: The Stationary Distributions Theorem is a fundamental result in probability theory that guarantees the existence and uniqueness of stationary distributions for certain stochastic processes.

theorem.statement: \[ \forall t \geq 0, \text{ if } P \text{ is a transition matrix for a Markov chain, then } \exists! \pi \in \Delta \text{ such that } \pi = \pi P. \]
theorem.proofSketch: The proof involves showing that the desired stationary distribution exists and is unique by using the fact that the Markov chain is ergodic.

intuition: In essence, this theorem states that for a given Markov chain, there exists a unique probability distribution that remains unchanged under iteration of the transition matrix. This has significant implications in many areas, including search engines and recommendation systems.
